quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I really believe in frameworks for things that helps drive extreme clarity.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A clear operating principle: use frameworks to reduce ambiguity and align teams quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: A lot of times I'm ramping up a new project, I'm like, "Where can I learn what I need to learn about this project?" I ask five different people, get five different answers. That is unacceptable.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights a common scaling failure mode—knowledge fragmentation—and sets a high bar for consistency.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Of course, I'm sure there's hundreds of docs associated with the project, but there needs to be one canonical doc. Everyone should know exactly where the canonical doc is.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A practical documentation methodology: designate a single source of truth to prevent confusion and rework.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: That's the one place I can go to get all the information I need about a project and it will link to all the other docs, things on the canonical doc are.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Defines what “canonical” means operationally: a hub doc that orients newcomers and points to deeper references.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: She joined what was then called Facebook as employee number 29 and has been at Meta for almost 20 years. She's seen the company scale from 30 employees to the one and a half trillion dollar business that it is today.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that frames why her process/clarity lessons come from operating through hypergrowth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Tired of bouncing around multiple tools to uncover what's really happening inside your product?
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Pendo)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-ops pain point—tool sprawl—that many teams can address by consolidating workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Pendo makes it easy to answer critical questions about how users are engaging with your product and then turn those insights into action, all so you can get your users to do what you actually want them to do.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Pendo)
quotes.context: A clear product-growth loop: measure engagement, derive insights, act on them to drive desired user behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, Pendo is built around product analytics, seeing what your users are actually doing in your apps so that you can optimize their experience.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Pendo)
quotes.context: Emphasizes behavior-based analytics (“actually doing”) as the foundation for improving product experience.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, you can save hours by completing security questionnaires with Vanta AI.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta)
quotes.context: A concrete efficiency claim practitioners can evaluate—using automation/AI to reduce compliance overhead.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You basically wrote your senior thesis at Stanford about why Facebook was going to win and why it was going to beat its competitors and the competitors cited I've never even heard of, so it's interesting that that was the competitor at the time.
quotes.speaker: Host (Lenny)
quotes.context: A memorable example of using deep, thesis-level conviction about a market to guide career decisions early.

quotes.topic_title: How Naomi joined Facebook as employee 29
quotes.text: It was right above the Jing Jing's Chinese restaurant in downtown Palo Alto and I just went to the office sort of cold called the equivalent of just walking into the office and seeing if there were any available jobs. There were not. I think I did that maybe five to 10 more times.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete example of persistence and unconventional outreach (repeated in-person cold approach) to break into a high-growth company.

quotes.topic_title: How Naomi joined Facebook as employee 29
quotes.text: I think it's because I definitely saw that there was product market fit. I saw that students at Stanford were obsessed with it, but it also had a long list of colleges that were really excited and on the waiting list to be accepted onto Facebook, and so there was this product market fit piece and also a huge demand from other audiences, other colleges, but our younger brothers and sisters were also sort of interested about Facebook and it seemed like it had this much broader appeal.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A practical PMF evaluation heuristic: combine intense local usage (“obsessed”) with observable pull from adjacent segments (waiting lists, younger cohorts).

quotes.topic_title: How Naomi joined Facebook as employee 29
quotes.text: Cheryl also talks about when you are on getting a rocket ship, don't ask what seat. That was my foot in the door and here we are 19 years later.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable career decision rule: prioritize joining a high-trajectory company over optimizing for the perfect initial role.

quotes.topic_title: How Naomi joined Facebook as employee 29
quotes.text: Yeah, it was pure just refusing to quit.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A blunt, repeatable principle for breaking in when you lack the “typical” credentials: persistence can be the differentiator.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into product management by doing the job
quotes.text: I ended up going, sort of the analogy, I went to the second floor most days after work, asked if there were any projects that I could help out with.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for breaking into a new function: consistently show up where the work happens and volunteer for real projects.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into product management by doing the job
quotes.text: It was very early days. There was always more to do than people to do it.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A situational heuristic: target environments with excess work relative to staffing to create opportunities to take on scope.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into product management by doing the job
quotes.text: And so eventually I picked up a few projects, helping with program management, giving my product feedback, and by the time that I actually applied formally to be a product manager, I had been doing the job voluntarily, almost informally for a few months.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A repeatable method for role transitions: do the job first (in small ways), then apply with proof of capability.

quotes.topic_title: Transitioning into product management by doing the job
quotes.text: I do think I sort of tried to create the luck by not giving up and just repeatedly cold calling or cold showing up or cold volunteering until I sort of was able to make it happen.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: “create luck” through persistent, proactive outreach and volunteering rather than waiting for formal openings.

quotes.topic_title: Head of Product at Meta: scope and responsibilities
quotes.text: There are a few thousand PMs at Meta. They do not all report to me. I would say a few hundred of them report to me on the teams that I directly manage, but I feel responsible for the entire PM community at Meta.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Clarifies a scaled leadership model: direct management of some, but stewardship and accountability for the whole PM org.

quotes.topic_title: Head of Product at Meta: scope and responsibilities
quotes.text: There are things that we do centrally, things like PM performance, PM culture PM onboarding and training, and that's the kind of thing that I look out for.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights the central “operating system” responsibilities that can raise PM effectiveness across a large organization.

quotes.topic_title: Head of Product at Meta: scope and responsibilities
quotes.text: I am deeply supportive of the PM function, and so I really care and I think PMs are a huge point of leverage in a company for how we can actually get stuff done and help accomplish the company's goals.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: investing in PMs is a leverage play for company execution and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Head of Product at Meta: scope and responsibilities
quotes.text: And so I sort of focus on PM as a really important exponential lever for doing that.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Reinforces the “exponential lever” framing—optimize the PM function to multiply impact rather than incrementally improve outputs.

quotes.topic_title: Mark Zuckerberg’s evolution and “learn-it-all” mindset
quotes.text: I always say Mark is a learn it all, not a know-it-all.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable mindset framework emphasizing continuous learning over projecting expertise.

quotes.topic_title: Mark Zuckerberg’s evolution and “learn-it-all” mindset
quotes.text: He is the fastest person at upskilling of anyone I've ever met.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights upskilling speed as a differentiator leaders can intentionally cultivate and prioritize.

quotes.topic_title: Mark Zuckerberg’s evolution and “learn-it-all” mindset
quotes.text: He used to do these annual challenges. One year I did them with him, it was learning Chinese, and within a year he was able to basically achieve an eighth grade fluency in Chinese.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete example of using time-boxed “annual challenges” as a method for rapid skill acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Mark Zuckerberg’s evolution and “learn-it-all” mindset
quotes.text: I think before in the early days, it just wasn't something that he was very comfortable with.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A reminder that even top leaders can start uncomfortable in key skills like public speaking and improve through deliberate practice.

quotes.topic_title: Mark Zuckerberg’s evolution and “learn-it-all” mindset
quotes.text: He's talked himself about coming across as a little scripted.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Normalizes early-stage communication awkwardness and suggests authenticity can be developed as confidence grows.

quotes.topic_title: A personal story: Mark as friend and mentor
quotes.text: But one of the lessons that we taught during that class that I remember Mark distinctly writing on the whiteboard, or not the whiteboard, there actually was chalk, it was with chalk on a chalkboard with the four life lessons. That was one, and I kept these for myself as well, love yourself. Two, only then can you truly serve others. Three, focus on what you can control. And four, for those things never give up.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concise four-step life framework that can be applied as a practical decision and resilience checklist.

quotes.topic_title: A personal story: Mark as friend and mentor
quotes.text: He asked me if I wanted to volunteer to teach a class in East Palo Alto after their school day.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete example of using service/volunteering as an actionable way to navigate a difficult personal period.

quotes.topic_title: A personal story: Mark as friend and mentor
quotes.text: And in retrospect, it's pretty funny, but Mark and I taught a class about how to build a business. So you had the CEO of Meta teaching this class to a bunch of middle school students, and we got really close to them through that process.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Illustrates an unconventional mentorship tactic—teaching beginners—to build deep relationships and reinforce fundamentals.

quotes.topic_title: A personal story: Mark as friend and mentor
quotes.text: For me number three is really the hardest, which is focus on what you can control. I think I probably think I can control more things than I actually can.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A candid reminder that overestimating control is common, making “control what you can” a high-leverage practice.

quotes.topic_title: How Meta’s “small group” leadership team operates
quotes.text: So I think the first thing is small group is sort of the leadership team. It's the leaders working on the most important projects at the company, sort of independent of reporting structure and stuff. It's like who are the leaders on the big most important projects or functions? They will be represented in small group.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Defines a project-centric leadership model that’s decoupled from org chart hierarchy, useful for scaling decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: How Meta’s “small group” leadership team operates
quotes.text: And the most dangerous kind of person to have in an organization is an agreeable taker.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that likability can mask self-interested behavior that harms the organization.

quotes.topic_title: How Meta’s “small group” leadership team operates
quotes.text: And the most precious person in an organization is the disagreeable giver.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable talent heuristic for valuing people who prioritize the company and challenge decisions directly.

quotes.topic_title: How Meta’s “small group” leadership team operates
quotes.text: One thing I think Mark has done really well in general is just have a culture, including on his leadership team, of people who give him feedback.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable leadership practice: deliberately building honest feedback loops at the top.

quotes.topic_title: How Meta’s “small group” leadership team operates
quotes.text: We also have one weekly operational meeting, which is highly structured where we go through all of the priority projects. The person who owns each of the projects will actually speak to the weekly updates for that project. And it's very operational and tactical.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operating cadence for execution: structured weekly reviews with direct owner reporting.

quotes.topic_title: Origins of the growth team and data-driven influence
quotes.text: Mark wasn't like, "You guys should create a growth team. Here's how you should operate."
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Challenges the assumption that iconic growth orgs are always founder-designed, implying teams can originate bottom-up.

quotes.topic_title: Origins of the growth team and data-driven influence
quotes.text: And so I think in some ways we established and grew a growth team and Mark got on board or saw the value in it and was a huge proponent of it, but I'm not sure it necessarily originated with him.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights a practical model for driving organizational change: prove value first, then earn executive sponsorship.

quotes.topic_title: Origins of the growth team and data-driven influence
quotes.text: And indeed, I think sometimes the focus on being so data- driven might've been something that myself, Alex Schultz, Javier Olavon, these are some of the original people that were on the growth team and that my closest coworkers now may have really pushed on and highlighted the value of for Mark.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Emphasizes that rigorous, data-driven practice can be championed by practitioners and “sold” upward through demonstrated value.

quotes.topic_title: Origins of the growth team and data-driven influence
quotes.text: One thing I wanted to start with is there's this legendary activation metric that you all had, the goal was to get, I think it was seven friends in 10 days or something like that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of an activation target that teams can adapt into a measurable onboarding milestone.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metric: seven friends in ten days
quotes.text: We had a notion though of growth accounting, which looks at what's our net growth every day? And that would look at the number of new users that registered minus the number of users that actually went stale. So after a 30-day period, that's how we define it, they no longer logged in. And then plus the number of users that resurrected, which is after 30 days they came back.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete growth accounting framework (new − stale + resurrected) practitioners can use to diagnose what’s actually driving net growth.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metric: seven friends in ten days
quotes.text: And what we found was the churn in resurrection lines were actually much larger than the new user line, which implied to us that retention and driving those two lines was actually our biggest lever to drive net growth.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A counterintuitive, data-driven conclusion that retention (not acquisition) can be the dominant lever for growth.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metric: seven friends in ten days
quotes.text: What we found was friending.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A crisp example of identifying the single behavioral variable most correlated with long-term engagement/retention.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metric: seven friends in ten days
quotes.text: And the other thing around 10 or 14 days is we wanted it to happen quickly, we wanted to have you experience the magic moment soon after you had registered on the site to prevent you from churning and then us having to resurrect you again.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Actionable onboarding principle: drive users to the “magic moment” fast to reduce early churn and avoid costly resurrection work.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metric: seven friends in ten days
quotes.text: the insight that we had is actually the product is the biggest lever to drive growth, and that means we should have a product and engineering team working on optimizing things like the registration flow, the invite flow, the new user onboarding, getting you seven friends in 10 days.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that growth is primarily a product/engineering problem, with concrete levers to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Understand–Identify–Execute and product-led growth mindset
quotes.text: the insight that we had is actually the product is the biggest lever to drive growth, and that means we should have a product and engineering team working on optimizing things like the registration flow, the invite flow, the new user onboarding, getting you seven friends in 10 days.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Reframes growth from a marketing/comms function to a product/engineering lever with concrete examples of what to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Understand–Identify–Execute and product-led growth mindset
quotes.text: One of my Naomi-isms is really understand, identify, and execute.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable framework for turning ambiguous growth problems into prioritized action.

quotes.topic_title: Understand–Identify–Execute and product-led growth mindset
quotes.text: And so in 2009 in January, we basically stopped doing anything on our roadmap except data instrumentation.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tactic: pause feature work to build measurement so you can find true drop-offs and levers.

quotes.topic_title: Understand–Identify–Execute and product-led growth mindset
quotes.text: Instead of having a foundation that's distributing money, we're going to build a product that actually raises money from our community. And many years later we've raised billions of dollars from the community for charity.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Shows how product-led thinking can replace traditional CSR with scalable, measurable impact—plus a concrete outcome.

quotes.topic_title: Understand–Identify–Execute and product-led growth mindset
quotes.text: why don't we build a version of Facebook that allows you to make translations in line? And so the community of people using Facebook at the time who actually knew the product the best could actually insert translations and there was a whole system that we built around how to up-rank the best translations and down-rank, sort of like Wikipedia.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A product/tech solution to a traditionally non-technical problem (localization) by leveraging community contributions with ranking mechanisms.

quotes.topic_title: Community-powered translation and scaling to 100+ languages
quotes.text: And I think we could have taken more of a non-technical traditional approach and had professional translators translate the entire site into the different languages, and instead sort of what the growth team suggested was why don't we build a version of Facebook that allows you to make translations in line?
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Shows a scalable product-led alternative to a traditional services approach by embedding translation directly into the product.

quotes.topic_title: Community-powered translation and scaling to 100+ languages
quotes.text: And so the community of people using Facebook at the time who actually knew the product the best could actually insert translations and there was a whole system that we built around how to up-rank the best translations and down-rank, sort of like Wikipedia.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Describes a community-powered quality-control mechanism (ranking/up-ranking) as a repeatable methodology for user-generated contributions.

quotes.topic_title: Community-powered translation and scaling to 100+ languages
quotes.text: And to this day, we have over 100 languages supported.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete outcome/data point demonstrating how the community-translation system enabled massive language scale.

quotes.topic_title: Community-powered translation and scaling to 100+ languages
quotes.text: So we're always trying to find these product technology solutions to these sort of traditional problems.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A generalizable product mindset: solve operational bottlenecks by building scalable product/tech systems instead of manual processes.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metrics as rallying points and onboarding creation
quotes.text: I think the majority of the value is in the latter, is just having extreme clarity around the goal and that allowed everybody to work towards optimizing the same goal.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights that activation metrics are most powerful as an alignment tool that focuses the whole org on one objective.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metrics as rallying points and onboarding creation
quotes.text: You're right, we did sort of just pick a point on the curve. I think it could have been any of those.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that the exact activation threshold matters less than choosing one and executing against it.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metrics as rallying points and onboarding creation
quotes.text: I mean, I think it doesn't matter, it's just that we picked one of them and what mattered there was we had the same goal, what mattered was that it was a retention goal or an activation metric.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Reinforces the methodology: pick a measurable activation/retention goal and use it as a shared rallying point.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metrics as rallying points and onboarding creation
quotes.text: I remember it was just like step one, upload your profile picture. That was really important so people could find you and know who you were. Step two, find your friends.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Gives a concrete onboarding sequence that drives users to the “magic moment” by removing early friction.

quotes.topic_title: Activation metrics as rallying points and onboarding creation
quotes.text: But that was not obvious to us at the time in 2006 that we had to explain to people how to use Facebook.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A cautionary lesson that what feels intuitive to builders (and early adopters) often requires explicit onboarding for new demographics.

quotes.topic_title: Macro vs micro barriers: friction removal tactics
quotes.text: Well, definitely the understand, identify, execute. I would just ask yourselves, do you have the data that you need to know what you need to do on growth? And if not, definitely take the time to instrument that data.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A simple growth methodology that emphasizes instrumentation and data readiness before running tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Macro vs micro barriers: friction removal tactics
quotes.text: And so for us growth, as much credit as we give to the growth team, I'm actually not sure how much credit we deserve and how much incremental growth we drove above and beyond the fact that this was a product that had product-market fit and we benefited in a huge amount from having high demand for the product.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that growth teams may be over-credited when product-market fit and demand are already strong.

quotes.topic_title: Macro vs micro barriers: friction removal tactics
quotes.text: So at every step, and I talked about the growth team, the projects that we were working on were really at a high level around removing barriers. There were macro barriers, like the first project I worked on was high school students on Facebook, which is an interesting story in and of itself because at that time we almost created a separate website called Facebook High just to keep them separate from the college students.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Introduces the macro vs. micro barriers framework and illustrates it with an early access-expansion decision.

quotes.topic_title: Macro vs micro barriers: friction removal tactics
quotes.text: What we found is 20% of people aren't actually confirming their email.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A concrete data point uncovered via flow instrumentation that highlights how small frictions can block activation at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Macro vs micro barriers: friction removal tactics
quotes.text: And so what we did was allow people to get notifications even as an unconfirmed account, and then if they clicked on any of those notifications, that would count as an account confirmation as well because they proved ownership of the email.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A specific friction-removal tactic that redefines “confirmation” based on user behavior to reduce drop-off in onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Naomi-isms and PMs as conductors
quotes.text: I really rely on Naomi-isms.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A practical approach to PM craft: codify repeatable principles you can apply across projects and teach to others.

quotes.topic_title: Naomi-isms and PMs as conductors
quotes.text: "A good PM looks for a way to make that more efficient,"
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A simple heuristic for day-to-day decision-making: continually reduce friction and increase leverage in how work gets done.

quotes.topic_title: Naomi-isms and PMs as conductors
quotes.text: And what I say is a PM is a conductor.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for PM scope: orchestrating cross-functional contributors rather than “owning” all the work directly.

quotes.topic_title: Naomi-isms and PMs as conductors
quotes.text: And as a PM, your job is to make sure everyone's playing their part correctly, every section in the orchestra is playing their part, but at the same time, they're playing together, they're unified in the music that they're producing and that they're playing at the right tempo.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Actionable definition of PM execution: align roles, ensure integration, and set operating cadence/tempo for the team.

quotes.topic_title: Naomi-isms and PMs as conductors
quotes.text: Important characteristics are the PM is not the star of the show.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that great PM impact often comes from enabling others rather than being the most visible contributor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth and product-learning discipline, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Emphasizes the dual goal of moving faster without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I left most was our experimentation platform where could set up experiments easily, troubleshoot issues, and analyze performance all on my own.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Points to the practical value of self-serve experimentation for speed and autonomy in growth teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, and accessible UI for diving deeper into performance and out of the box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Offers a concrete benefit (shaving weeks off) plus a methodology angle (advanced statistical methods) tied to faster iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo also makes it easy for you to share experiment insight with your team, sparking new ideas for the A/B testing flywheel.
quotes.speaker: Naomi Gleit
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable growth mechanism—sharing learnings to fuel an experimentation flywheel.
